Characteristics and 2-year outcme data for the ARCR_Pred study: the Swiss-wide multicenter cohort for the evaluation and prediction of core outcomes in arthroscopic rotator cuff repair Chapter 1 About

Characteristics and 2-year outcme data for the ARCR_Pred study: the Swiss-wide multicenter cohort for the evaluation and prediction of core outcomes in arthroscopic rotator cuff repair T. Stojanov 2024-03-08 Chapter 1 About This is a report example of a data science project written in Markdown. The ARCR_Pred study was initiated in June 2020. Last patient was recruited in November 2021. The data comes from a REDCap database, designed for the purpose of the study. We needed about one year to monitor the data, using monitoring lists and resolve the opened data queries via our Electronic Data Capture (EDC) system. More information can be found here: https://arcr-pred.ch and in Audig√© et al. (2021). References
Chapter 2 Data management 2.1 Load packages 2.2 Load data Data inspection 2.3 Variable modification 2.4 Variable creation 2.5 Data save

Chapter 2 Data management In this section, we will prepare the data for data analysis. 2.1 Load packages The following packages will be used. library(haven) # to use as_factor() function library(tidyverse) # to use the pipe function %>% along with data management tools 2.2 Load data For this work, we need two data sets: data: for all enrolled patients screening: for all screened patients We use here the function called read_dta() to call dta files coming from a STATA export. data <- haven::read_dta("data/arcrpred-02-BaseFU-sp006-data-2024-01-21_1703.dta") screening <- haven::read_dta("data/arcrpred-02a-screening-2023-01-16_1444.dta") Data inspection We use here the function called head to inspect the data. data |> head() ## We see that the factors variables are contained in a haven_labelled format (this is the same for the screening dataset). With the function labelled::is.labelled() and haven::as_factor(), we convert the labelled versions of the variables to factors: data <- data %>% #for data set dplyr::mutate_if( #transform labelled variables into factors labelled::is.labelled, haven::as_factor ) %>% dplyr::mutate_if( is.double, as.numeric ) screening <- screening %>% dplyr::mutate_if( #transform labelled variables into factors labelled::is.labelled, haven::as_factor ) %>% dplyr::mutate_if( is.double, as.numeric ) 2.3 Variable modification There are a bunch of variables we need to modify before being analyzed in the next chapters. 2.3.1 Change variable format We need to modify the values for specific variables so that they become ordinal. Here, we use the across() function in order to select specific variables and apply the same transformation. 2.3.1.1 anspoconf, anspomot, worksat, workmot data <- data %>% mutate( across(c("anspoconf", "anspomot", "worksat", "workmot"), ~ as.integer(case_when( .x == "Not at all0" ~ "0", .x == "Fully10" ~ "10", TRUE ~as.character(.x))) )) 2.3.1.2 pain1wo data <- data %>% mutate( pain1wo = as.integer(case_when( pain1wo == "No pain0" ~ "0", pain1wo == "Intolerable pain10" ~ "10", TRUE ~ as.character(pain1wo) )) ) 2.3.1.3 sleepnrs data <- data %>% mutate( sleepnrs = as.integer(case_when( sleepnrs == "Best possiblesleep0" ~ "0", sleepnrs == "Worst possiblesleep10" ~ "10", TRUE ~ as.character(sleepnrs) )) ) 2.3.1.4 rom parameters data <- data %>% mutate( across(c("rm_ante_bakt", "rm_abd_bakt", "rm_abdgh_bpas", "rm_ar0_bakt", "rm_ar0gh_bpas", "rm_ar90_bpas", "rm_ir90_bpas"), ~ as.integer( substring(., 1, nchar(as.character(.))-1) ))) 2.3.1.5 age screening$LogAge <- as.numeric(screening$LogAge) 2.3.2 Variables re-categorization 2.3.2.1 education2 There, we relied on the Swiss Minimal Dataset for Orthopedics to guide our choices. data <- data %>% dplyr::mutate( education2 = case_when( education %in% c("Compulsory school", "No education") ~ "Up to 9 years of education", education %in% c("Apprenticeship", "High school") ~ "10 to 13 years of education", education %in% c("Higher professional education", "University, College") ~ "13+ years of education" )) %>% dplyr::select(-education) data$education2 <- factor(data$education2, levels = c("Up to 9 years of education", "10 to 13 years of education", "13+ years of education")) 2.3.2.2 start_active_movements_modif There, we categorize the start_active_movements variable into a 3-category variable. data = data |> dplyr::mutate( start_active_movements_modif = as.factor(case_when( start_active_movements %in% c("At day 1", "After 1 week", "After 2 weeks", "After 3 weeks", "After 4 weeks (1 month)", "After 5 weeks") ~ "0-5 weeks", start_active_movements %in% c("After 6 weeks") ~ "6 weeks", start_active_movements %in% c("After 7 weeks", "After 8 weeks (2 months)", "After 9 weeks", "After 10 weeks", "After 11 weeks", "After 12 weeks (3 months)") ~ "6-12 weeks", TRUE ~ as.character(start_active_movements)))) 2.3.2.3 start_passive_movements_modif There, we categorize the start_passive_movements variable into a 3-category variable. data = data |> dplyr::mutate( start_passive_movements_modif = as.factor(case_when( start_passive_movements %in% c("At day 1", "After 1 week", "After 2 weeks", "After 3 weeks", "After 4 weeks (1 month)", "After 5 weeks") ~ "0-5 weeks", start_passive_movements %in% c("After 6 weeks") ~ "6 weeks", start_passive_movements %in% c("After 7 weeks", "After 8 weeks (2 months)", "After 9 weeks", "After 10 weeks", "After 11 weeks", "After 12 weeks (3 months)") ~ "6-12 weeks", TRUE ~ as.character(start_passive_movements)))) 2.3.2.4 nbrearcr Considering the very low number of patients having a surgeon who performed less than 20 ARCR per year, we decided to combine the two adjacent categories for nbrearcr. data = data |> dplyr::mutate( nbrearcr = as.factor(case_when( nbrearcr %in% c("1-20", ">20-50") ~ "<50", TRUE ~ as.character(nbrearcr)))) data$nbrearcr <- factor(data$nbrearcr, levels = c("<50", ">50-100", ">100" ) ) 2.3.2.5 eq5d5l05_modif Considering the very low number of patients being extremenly anxious or depressed, we decided to combine the three adjacent categories for eq5d5l05 variable. data <- data |> dplyr::mutate( eq5d5l05_modif = as.factor( case_when( eq5d5l05 == "I am extremely anxious or depressed" ~ "At least moderately anxious or depressed", eq5d5l05 == "I am severely anxious or depressed" ~ "At least moderately anxious or depressed", eq5d5l05 == "I am moderately anxious or depressed" ~ "At least moderately anxious or depressed", TRUE ~ as.character(eq5d5l05) ) ) ) data$eq5d5l05_modif <- factor(data$eq5d5l05_modif, levels = c("I am not anxious or depressed", "I am slightly anxious or depressed", "At least moderately anxious or depressed" ) ) 2.3.2.6 immrifatisprepair Here, we probably need a bit of an explanation. We would like to have the highest level of fatty infiltration observed across the 3 tendons. This is why we created the following variable: immrifatrepair_modif. data <- data |> dplyr::mutate( immrifatisprepair = case_when( is.na(sgispsuture) ~ NA, TRUE ~ as.character(immrifatisp)), immrifatssprepair = case_when( is.na(sgsspsuture) ~ NA, TRUE ~ as.character(immrifatssp)), immrifatsscrepair = case_when( is.na(sgsscsuture) ~ NA, TRUE ~ as.character(immrifatssc))) |> tidyr::unite( "immrifatrepair", immrifatisprepair, immrifatssprepair, immrifatsscrepair, na.rm = T, sep = ", ") |> dplyr::mutate( immrifatrepair_modif = as.factor(case_when( str_detect(immrifatrepair, "4") ~ "Stage 3-4", str_detect(immrifatrepair, "3") ~ "Stage 3-4", str_detect(immrifatrepair, "2") ~ "Stage 2", str_detect(immrifatrepair, "1") ~ "Stage 1", str_detect(immrifatrepair, "0") ~ "Stage 0" ))) 2.3.3 analcohol The number of patients owing to the variable category Several times a day was deemed too low. We therefore decided to re-combine the two adjacent categories 1x daily and Several times a day. data = data |> dplyr::mutate( analcohol_modif = as.factor( case_when( analcohol == "1x daily" ~ "At least daily", analcohol == "Several times a day" ~ "At least daily", TRUE ~ as.character(analcohol) ) ) ) data$analcohol_modif <- factor(data$analcohol_modif, levels = c("No", "Occasionally", "At least daily" ) ) 2.3.4 asa The number of patients owing to category IV of the ASA Classification was deemed too low. We therefore decided to recombine the two adjacent categories into one. data = data |> dplyr::mutate( asa_modif = as.factor( case_when( asa == "III" ~ "III-IV", asa == "IV" ~ "III-IV", TRUE ~ as.character(asa) ) ) ) data$asa_modif <- factor(data$asa_modif, levels = c("I", "II", "III-IV" ) ) 2.4 Variable creation Here, we create a variable distinguishing between private and public hospitals. We need also to tell the variable which clinic owes to which type of hospital. We used the map showed in Figure 2.1 to prepare this variable. Figure 2.1: Geographical distribution of ARCR_Pred cohort study centers. Note: Yellow and blue text indicate public and private hospital study centers, respectively. Study centers located at the same city are listed alphabetically. data <- data %>% mutate( hosptype = case_when( Clinic %in% c("ART", "END", "GUT", "HUG", "HIR", "INM", "SON", "KWS") ~ "Private", TRUE ~ "Public" ) ) screening <- screening %>% mutate( hosptype = case_when( Clinic %in% c("ART", "END", "GUT", "HUG", "HIR", "INM", "SON", "KWS") ~ "Private", TRUE ~ "Public" ) ) 2.5 Data save We save the data ready for use in the following chapters. save(data, screening, file = "01-results.RData") rm(list = ls(all.names = TRUE)) #will clear all objects includes hidden objects. gc() ## used (Mb) gc trigger (Mb) max used (Mb) ## Ncells 3778480 201.8 6054084 323.4 6054084 323.4 ## Vcells 7717291 58.9 89742068 684.7 218652273 1668.2

Chapter 3 Recruitment Data In this section, we will describe how we built specific tables describing the recruitment and more specifically the screening log data. 3.1 Load packages library(knitr) #to load the image library(tidyverse) #for data manipulation library(gtsummary) #to design table library(knitr) library(writexl) 3.2 Participating sites We recruited patients across 18 sites in Switzerland and one in Germany. See Figure 3.1, which all the participating sites in the ARCR_Pred study. Figure 3.1: Geographical distribution of ARCR_Pred cohort study centers. Note: Yellow and blue text indicate public and private hospital study centers, respectively. Study centers located at the same city are listed alphabetically. 3.3 Study representativity We asked participating sites to provide us with a list of patients undergoing an arthroscopic rotator cuff repair (ARCR) over their own period of recruitment. The underlying idea was to assess our selection bias by comparing the population of enrolled patients to the population of not enrolled but eligible patients. For all not enrolled patients, sites were asked to retrieve the following information, prospectively or retrospectively: Sex Year of birth Tear severity I download the data set coming from the last section of the previous chapter 2.5. load("01-results.RData") 3.3.1 Comparison of enrolled and not enrolled patients Below, I use the gtsummary package, which allows to do nice-looking summary tables ready for publications. In Table 3.1, we compare the populations of enrolled to not enrolled patients. We will focus on key selected variables, such as age, sex, tear severity and the OSS, reported in the questionnaire. Chapter 4 Overall Cohort Description In this section, we will describe how we got our tables and figures described in our manuscript. 4.1 Load packages library(tidyverse) library(knitr) library(gt) library(gtsummary) 4.2 Load data I download the data set coming from the previous section of the previous chapter 2.5. load("01-results.RData") I merge the two data sets to prepare my final data set using the full_join() function from the dplyr package. dataorig <- dplyr::full_join( data, screening, by = "ptn" ) data <- dataorig |> pivot_wider( id_cols = ptn, names_from = event, names_prefix = "event_", values_from = -names(data)[1:2] ) Below, I filter the data to have only the patients that were enrolled in the study using the filter() function from the dplyr package: data <- data %>% dplyr::filter( enrolled_event_Baseline == "Enrolled" ) data <- data %>% mutate( hosptype = hosptype.x_event_Baseline ) %>% dplyr::select( -hosptype.x_event_Baseline, -hosptype.y_event_Baseline ) 4.3 Chapter 5 Modeling 2-year outcome data load(file = "cohort-desc.Rdata") load(file = "dataorig.RData") library(report) library(tidyverse) library(nlme) library(lme4) For some variables, we have missing values, while the value should remain the same (e.g.¬†educational level), I used the package zoo to use the last observation carried forward function. This way, we have complete data useable for next steps of multilevel modelling. library(zoo) dataorig$education2 <- na.locf(dataorig$education2, na.rm = T) dataorig$sgopsurgeon <- na.locf(dataorig$sgopsurgeon, na.rm = T) dataorig$nbrearcr <- na.locf(dataorig$nbrearcr, na.rm = T) dataorig$expyrsshoulder <- na.locf(dataorig$expyrsshoulder, na.rm = T) dataorig$analcohol_modif <- na.locf(dataorig$analcohol_modif, na.rm = T) dataorig$ansmoking<- na.locf(dataorig$ansmoking, na.rm = T) dataorig$bmi <- na.locf(dataorig$bmi, na.rm = T) dataorig$ansincew <- na.locf(dataorig$ansincew, na.rm = T) dataorig$ansmokingyn <- na.locf(dataorig$ansmokingyn, na.rm = T) dataorig$immrifatrepair_modif <- na.locf(dataorig$immrifatrepair_modif, na.rm = T) dataorig$eq5d5l05_modif <- na.locf(dataorig$eq5d5l05_modif, na.rm = T) dataorig$asa_modif <- na.locf(dataorig$asa_modif, na.rm = T) datamodel = dataorig |> dplyr::mutate( ptn = as.factor(ptn), Clinic = as.factor(Clinic.x), pain1wo = 1 - pain1wo ) |> dplyr::mutate_at( c("cs", "ssv", "oss", "pain1wo"), ~ round(scales::rescale(., to = c(0,100)), digits = 0) # convert on a 0-100 scale ) 5.1 Generate model objects cs <- lmer( data = datamodel, formula = cs ~ event2*hosptype.x + Age + gender + eq5d5l05_modif + education2 + bmi + ansmokingyn + analcohol_modif + tearsev + asa_modif + (1 | Clinic/ptn)) cs_model <- cs |> report_table() |> as.data.frame() oss <- lmer( data = datamodel, formula = oss ~ event2*hosptype.x + Age + gender + eq5d5l05_modif + education2 + bmi + ansmokingyn + analcohol_modif + tearsev + asa_modif + (1 | Clinic/ptn)) oss_model <- oss |> report_table() |> as.data.frame() pain1wo <- lmer( data = datamodel, formula = pain1wo ~ event2*hosptype.x + Age + gender + eq5d5l05_modif + education2 + bmi + ansmokingyn + analcohol_modif + tearsev + asa_modif + (1 | Clinic/ptn)) pain1wo_model <- pain1wo |> report_table() |> as.data.frame() ssv <- lmer( data = datamodel, formula = ssv ~ event2*hosptype.x + Age + gender + eq5d5l05_modif + education2 + bmi + ansmokingyn + analcohol_modif + tearsev + asa_modif + (1 | Clinic/ptn)) ssv_model <- ssv |> report_table() |> as.data.frame() cs_model2 <- cs_model |> dplyr::select( Parameter, Coefficient, CI_low, CI_high, Group, Fit ) |> dplyr::mutate( across(c(Coefficient, CI_low, CI_high), ~ round(.x, digits = 1)), across(c(Fit), ~ round(.x, digits = 2)) ) |> dplyr::mutate( Parameter = dplyr::case_when( is.na(Parameter) ~ Group, TRUE ~ as.character(Parameter) ), Coefficient = dplyr::case_when( is.na(Coefficient) ~ Fit, TRUE ~ Coefficient ) ) |> dplyr::select( -Group, -Fit ) |> tidyr::unite("Constant-Score", c(Coefficient, CI_low), sep = " (", na.rm = T) |> tidyr::unite("Constant-Score", as.character(`Constant-Score`) ) ) oss_model2 <- oss_model |> dplyr::select( Parameter, Coefficient, CI_low, CI_high, Group, Fit ) |> dplyr::mutate( across(c(Coefficient, CI_low, CI_high), ~ round(.x,
